xml.line: ...I did a little research. I looked into those special Psyche-Locks you mentioned, Mr. Nick.
You did? That's great! I really appreciate it.
A red Psyche-Lock protects a secret that a person is consciously trying to hide. If the person folds under questioning, the lock breaks and the truth comes out.
Yup. That's exactly how I got the truth out of Detective Fulbright and Director Cosmos.
But a black Psyche-Lock protects a secret from the deepest place in a person's heart... ...a secret that that person isn't even consciously aware of.
So even they don't know it's there...
Athena isn't trying to keep anything from you on purpose. For some reason, part of her heart and her memories are sealed off, even from herself.
Okay, so all I have to do is break the Psyche-Locks!
According to my research... A black Psyche-Lock is like a heavy chain wrapped directly around one's heart. If they are ripped off by force, it could cause permanent damage to a person's soul.
(In other words, if I'm not careful, I could traumatize Athena for good... *gulp*) Pearls, could you stay by Athena's side? She must be suffering under the weight of such a heavy burden.
All right... But will you be all right by yourself, Mr. Nick?
I'm up against Edgeworth. I have to be able to give this trial all of my focus and strength!
And you can't do that if I'm there... I'll just hold you back...
No, that's not it! I just meant I can relax and concentrate if I knew you were with Athena. You're the only one who can do it, Pearls.
All right. I'll do it, then! Good luck, Mr. Nick!
(Good. Now that my mind is at ease, I'd better get ready. I'll just tidy up the evidence and take out what I don't need... It's time to end this nightmare that started seven years ago!)
(Defense, prosecution, and judge. There are even people in the gallery. The roof has been completely blown off and the walls have collapsed... ...but today, this ruin is my battleground!)
Court, or some facsimile thereof, is now in session for the trial of Athena Cykes.
Aura:
Please try not to upset Ms. Blackquill... I'm begging you...
Umm... Court is now in session for the very serious and very proper trial of Athena Cykes.
Hmph. This is no trial. It's nothing more than a ridiculous farce.
Wh-What did you say?!
Edgeworth! Did you not hear what I said to His Honor?!

However, this ridiculous farce has a very important meaning for our legal system. Recall the case of the UR-Incident, in which a prosecutor was found guilty of murder. That case ushered in the odious "dark age of the law."
I see what you're after... If we can find the real truth behind that case today...
Precisely. The darkness will be dispelled and glory shall be restored to the court system.
Prosecutor Edgeworth, you sound as if you know something of this "truth"...?
I do indeed. A new suspect has emerged in the UR-1 case. For seven years, Simon Blackquill has refused to speak in order to cover for someone else.
(Brace yourself, Phoenix. Here it comes...)
I'm sorry, Wright, but the situation is what it is, and I must do what I must. The prosecution moves to indict Athena Cykes on the count of murder in the first degree!
Regardless the circumstance, I intend to question the defendant with all I have. For that is a part of my creed.
Then you better bring it.
If the two of you are ready... Court is now in session for the trial of Athena Cykes!
Your Honor, the defense was born ready!
Tsk tsk. The prosecution is also ready.
(This immense tension between us... It's like we're picking up right where we left off.)
It's my duty to clear Prosecutor Blackquill of false accusations and end this insanity.

But I have no intention of losing Ms. Cykes, either. She's a very promising young lawyer! (I know without a doubt that Athena is innocent... ...but I don't think Prosecutor Blackquill did it, either.)
So... do you have any clue who was responsible for the sabotage...?
At the very least, I know it wasn't Simon Blackquill. I don't know enough to identify the true culprit, but it's clear WHAT that person is. To put it simply............ a spy.
(The true culprit is a spy. It's going to be hard to convince anyone of that when I barely believe it myself... ...but I don't a choice if I want to save Athena and Blackquill and expose the spy!)
Now, then, Chief Prosecutor Edgeworth...
Hmph... No need for the "Chief Prosecutor" bit, Your Honor. I am here as a simple prosecutor.
Very well. Your opening statement, please, Prosecutor Edgeworth. Although, I've been known of late to give an impressive opening statement myself...
In all the trials I have ever seen, only the prosecution gives an opening statement...
O-Of course. You're right! I was just joking -- just having a little fun!
(So he wasn't doing them just out of fear... Interesting...)

Let's start with a brief overview of the UR-Incident. The incident occurred at the Cosmos Space Center seven years ago, on October 7th. The victim, psychologist Metis Cykes, was killed in the robotics lab on the fourth floor.
(Athena's mother...)

Simon Blackquill, a young prosecutor at the time, was found guilty of the crime. There were two deciding factors that led to his guilty verdict: One: Blackquill was the only person in the corridor to the lab at the time of the murder. And two: this photo, which captured the moment of the crime.
Hmm... Very incriminating evidence indeed... It would appear that the only conclusion is that Prosecutor Blackquill did indeed--
Aura:
Excuse me, Ms. Blackquill, but we must follow proper procedure for these things, you know...
Or perhaps we should heed her wishes, Your Honor. She is the trial's sponsor, after all. Besides, the courtroom is chilly, and sitting for too long can't be good for your back.
Oh! You are very kind to show such concern for the welfare of the elderly...
(As skilled as ever at playing the court puppeteer, I see.)
The prosecution calls its first witness. A witness... who decided to bring forth new testimony after seven long years!
(New testimony...? And just who IS this witness, anyway?)
Bobby Fulbright's the name! In justice we trust!
What are YOU doing here...?
I'm just here to speak for the hostage-taker, Ms. Aura Blackquill. She says she's too busy, what with confining and threatening the hostages and all.
(That doesn't seem to stop her from constantly chiming in through Clonco...)
I'm nothing more than an observer in this. Do your best! I'm watching you...
Believing her brother innocent, Ms. Blackquill has been conducting her own investigation. And though her current actions are hardly lawful, I think we can at least hear her theory.
I have here Ms. Blackquill's notes on the investigation she conducted. And I'll be giving testimony based on these notes! Here I go!
"Simon isn't the murderer. He was trying to cover for someone."

And that's Ms. Blackquill's theory! It totally goes in the face of the official ruling, huh! About the case she mentions, there were other rolling cases like that one in the lab. But they're not for traveling -- they're apparently for moving parts and equipment.
(I vaguely remember seeing three cases, all different sizes.)

At the last trial, they thought that Prosecutor Blackquill used the case to steal the rock. And they had a perfectly good reason to think that, too! You see, there's a security camera in the corridor that leads to the robotics lab. And that camera captured footage of Blackquill leaving the scene with the case!
(I can see why that footage helped to bring his trial to a quick end. It's very convincing, that's for sure...)
That case, by the way, was later discovered outside on the Space Center grounds!
Speaking of after the incident, where was the defendant, Athena Cykes, found?

She was found on the fifth floor of the Space Center, in the Cykes family residence. Prosecutor Blackquill most likely brought her there after the incident. In addition, it's unknown where Ms. Cykes was at the estimated time of death.
Ms. Cykes was too confused by the shock of her mother's death to give proper testimony. And there was no witness or evidence to tell us where she might have been...
So what you're saying is, Ms. Cykes didn't have an alibi?
...That is what the evidence is saying, yes.
Hmm... I understand the reasoning behind the theory, but I'm far from convinced. The victim is the accused's mother. Are you actually claiming an eleven-year-old girl...?
...Hmph. Of course, the girl had a very strong motive.
Dr. Cykes was a psychologist who wrote many papers about speech and emotions. You're aware of Athena Cykes's special ability, aren't you, Your Honor?!
Are you referring to that therapy thing? Yes, she's done it quite a few times in court!
The ability to read emotions from speech, and the subject of her mother's research.
Well, as long as it benefits society, I don't see any particular problem researching it...
(I don't like where this is heading... Not one bit!)
Dr. Cykes was so intent on her research, she forced her daughter to undergo experiments.
Prosecutor Edgeworth! Are you seriously suggesting...?!

I've done my best to be delicate, but even you can't deny it to be true, Mr. Wright. No longer able to withstand the anguish of the experiments... ...Ms. Cykes felt her only choice was to kill her own mother!
Aaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaagh!
Order! Order in the court! What a tragic story... I hardly want to believe it myself. But we must proceed. Mr. Wright, if you could. Detective Fulbright, please refer to the notes.
"Simon isn't the murderer. He was trying to cover for someone."
Phoenix:
Yes, that is precisely what Ms. Blackquill appears to believe!
And that is what I believe as well. Prosecutor Blackquill is no murderer, Mr. Wright.
But Athena Cykes certainly didn't kill anyone, either, Mr. Edgeworth.
So it appears neither of us can afford to go easy on the other. Fine. I expected no less.
Ooh, I remember this tense atmosphere! It's so... invigorating!
I'm only reading notes here, but yeah! I feel extra invigorated, too! So, let's keep going!
"Someone else was at the scene at the time they say Simon committed the murder."
Phoenix:
Edgeworth:
Phoenix:
Edgeworth:
Fine, so maybe I jumped the gun by a teeny-weeny bit...
Ha ha ha ha ha! Now I know what they mean when they say "close enough to argue"! ...Moving on!
"I mean, if he really was out to steal that moon rock, then why the rolling case?"
Phoenix:
Yes, that's the one. And Ms. Blackquill has drawn a conclusion from these two photos.
She has?! And what is that conclusion?!
You're the one with her notes!
Oh, right. Of course. Reading them now! So, why the rolling case...?
"Because he was using it to hide someone inside. That's why."
Phoenix:
Hmph. Have you forgotten that we saw just such a thing only the other day? At your own daughter's magic show, she fit a grown person into a small box.
Oh, yeah... (Way to ruin the memory of a good day!)
A magic show! I wish you would have thought to invite me...!
Actually, I would've liked to go, too!
Uh, m-my apologies. I'll invite you both next time. I promise. (So... Wait a minute. What were we talking about again?)
Prosecutor Blackquill was using the case to hide someone.
"And the only person small enough to fit inside that case... was Athena Cykes!"
Phoenix:
In that case, what do YOU think Prosecutor Blackquill had in that case?
I think it was... the moon rock...
Edgeworth:
Phoenix:
Hmph. Then let me ask you this... Can you come up with a better theory of what was in the case?
Well, Mr. Wright? Can you?
(Yikes. Give a guy some time to think... Let's see... Should I try to bluff my way through what could have been in that case?)
(I guess I'd better wait and see how it goes.)
(It's a clever theory, but it doesn't look like they have any solid proof. If I push, maybe I can uncover some flaws in it.)
I know exactly what Prosecutor Blackquill carried from the scene. (I just have to find something else that was missing, right? No sweat!)
Ooh, I'd be very interested in hearing your theory... if it's true, that is.

This is a crime scene photo taken after Prosecutor Blackquill left, correct? All we have to do is compare this with... ...this photo of Prosecutor Blackquill to see what's missing. If he took something with him, then it should be in one of these photos! (Lady Luck, don't fail me now...)
All right then, Mr. Wright. Let us hear your theory. What did Prosecutor Blackquill take from the scene of the murder?
Leads to:
Phoenix:
...I'm afraid I never heard mention of that being removed from the crime scene...
............ (He saw straight through that!)
Tell me you have something more substantial than that, Wright!
Well, I have something more substantial for him: a penalty.

(I'd better compare the two photos again. Okay, in this photo, I see... ...the operating table, the katana, a cart... and the stuff on said cart... Are any of those things different in this photo taken after the incident?)

Please note that there is a robot part on top of the cart in this photo. However, in this photo taken after the crime, the robot part is gone. In other words, this part is something that was taken from the scene of the crime!
Hmm... You do appear to be right. I don't see it in the second picture.
But it's just a piece of junk. How important could it be?
(Is it really just an insignificant robot part? ............Speaking of which...)
Wh-What are you looking at?! I'm gonna start charging for each glance, per eyeball!
(Stingy, stingy. What happened to the age of free previews?) *ahem* Your Honor, about this robot part... Doesn't it look like it could be an arm from that robot there?
Well! Now that you mention it, it does, doesn't it. But the case is still too big to be practical for just the moon rock and a robot arm.

(But was it really just the one arm that was in there? If it wasn't Athena in the case, then maybe...) I believe there was another robot at the scene that looks just like the one here. Your Honor, it is the defense's assertion that it was this other robot that was in the case!
Wh-Whaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaat?!
Edgeworth:
Phoenix:
But, Mr. Wright! I thought you were more of the technologically illiterate type. When did you become such an expert? I feel... somehow abandoned...
Not to worry, Your Honor. I still know next to nothing about machines. But I know this piece of evidence proves which robot the arm belonged to!
Leads to:
Phoenix:
It's perfectly conclusive... of your utter incompetence.
(Can't you be normal for once and simply say, "That's wrong!"?)
You've conclusively earned yourself a penalty as well, Mr. Wright.
(Well, given the arm's distinctive feature, this is one conclusion that won't escape me!) I may not know my hard disk from my floppy drive...
The robot in this picture is named Ponco. But take a look at Ponco's arm. It was Ms. Cykes who bandaged it up that like.
She must have thought that machines heal in the same way that people do. What an adorable, naïve mistake! It reminds me of my own grandchild...
The robot arm at the crime scene had the same bandaging wrapped around it. In other words, this robot arm could belong to none other than Ponco!
Order in the court! Order, I say! Prosecutor Edgeworth, what do you have to say to this?!

I concede that the robot is about the same size as a child. But it cannot grab its knees and curl itself up into a ball. Even if it was the largest of the cases, the robot couldn't have possibly fit in there!
The case does comes [sic] up to about mid-thigh on Prosecutor Blackquill. Hmm... I see your point. The robot is much taller than that.
(They've got me there... So then, did Prosecutor Blackquill make Ponco fit into the case by...?)
Couldn't he have crunched Ponco up and compacted her a bit? You know, kind of like... ...when you suck the air out of those storage bags with a vacuum cleaner?

...Hmm. Interesting theory. Why don't we conduct an experiment, then? Detective Fulbright, could you please bring us a storage bag and a vacuum cleaner? Let's try to compact Mr. Wright here, and see if we can't fit him in the rubbish bin.
............On second thought, let's just scrap the whole idea and start over, okay?
Very well, but one man's trash is that same man's penalty.
Gah!
Of course Ponco would fit. All Prosecutor Blackquill had to do was dismantle her. Once taken apart, the robot could have easily fit inside that rolling case!
Hmm... It appears to be a robot-assembly device.
"Disassemble anything in a flash! Push the 'Dismantle' button!" That sounds pretty neat! Can I push it, Mr. Nick?
Hmm... It sounds rather violent, but Mr. Wright does have a point there.
Edgeworth:
Phoenix:
Y-You mean... the sword?
Yes, Your Honor. Ms. Blackquill, I'd like your opinion as a woman of science. Isn't it true that the katana could have been used to take the robot apart?!
I... I suppose so...! Their joints aren't made of a very tough material. A blade could slice through them.

Thank you for your expert opinion, Ms. Blackquill. Thanks to you, we now know... ...that the existence of the severed arm in this photo proves that Ponco was taken apart. In addition, since the rest of Ponco was not found at the scene, we can conclude that... ...the true meaning of this photo is very different from the original interpretation.
...Y-You can't mean...?!

That's exactly what I mean. This photo does NOT capture the moment of the murder. It is instead a picture of the moment after the robot was sliced apart. The blood you see where the arm was cut off was transferred there by the bloody katana. Most likely, the rest of Ponco is scattered around Prosecutor Blackquill's feet...
Not hearing this...!
Therefore, what was transported inside that case was not the defendant, but a robot! Ms. Cykes never was at the scene at the time of the murder!
Nnnnngh... AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAGH! ...My head! My head! My body! Where am I?! Gaaagh!
Order! Order in the court!
It's true that Ponco was found in pieces after the murder... And I'll admit I repaired her myself afterwards.
(Yes! I'm finally making some progress! Hopefully, I've gotten at least one step closer... ...to proving both Athena and Prosecutor Blackquill innocent...)
Edgeworth:
(All right... What's going on here? It's never good when he plays things this straight...)
Does the prosecution withdraw its claim that the defendant was carried from the scene?
No, Your Honor. My claim hasn't changed.
Phoenix:
Edgeworth:
(Edgeworth... He's been one step ahead of me this whole time!)
In that case, how do you propose the defendant left the crime scene?
Simple. The footage only shows Prosecutor Blackquill from behind. What's more... ...he's holding his arm in front of his body, as if he were holding something, or someone...
That's hardly evidence.
I have proof: the surcoat Prosecutor Blackquill was wearing. The victim's blood was found on the front of it and the stain had a highly distinctive shape.
A bloodstain? With a distinctive shape? Please continue, Prosecutor Edgeworth.
Seven years ago, the defendant was known to constantly wear a certain item... ...of which there is only one in the world: a special pair of headphones made just for her.
She always wore these big, heavy-looking headphones. She said her mother made them for her, as part of her research.

Analysis showed the bloodstain to be in the exact same shape as these headphones. In other words, this was no mere blood splatter. The blood went from the victim's body... to the headphones... and then... ...was imprinted onto Prosecutor Blackquill's coat like a stamp.
A most gruesome stamp, indeed...

Blackquill carried Ms. Cykes, who had been hit by splatter, away from the crime scene. This proves that Athena Cykes was, without question, present at the crime scene. And that... concludes the prosecution's argument.
Ngaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaagh!
Order! ...If the defendant was indeed at the scene, it deepens the suspicion against her.
Phoenix:
Edgeworth:
(I don't really think that, no, but...) You can't say the possibility isn't there! Detective Fulbright, was the robot questioned at the time?
No, I don't see any record of it. I believe it was considered "unrelated to the case."
But, as it turned out, the robot was actually integrally related. Your Honor, the defense would like to call Ponco to the stand!
A r-robot witness?! Order! Order in the court! ...Prosecutor Edgeworth, what do you think about this?
Hmph. Mr. Wright has called all manner of witnesses to the stand over the years. So why not a robot? Nothing surprises me anymore with him.
Very well. I will allow the witness. ...Bailiff! Please summon the robot named Ponco!
Witness, please state your name and occupation.
My name is not "witness"! My name is Ponco!
Yes, I realize that. But when you are at the witness stand, you are the "witness."
No, I'm not! I'm Ponco! Say it with me! "Ponco"!
What an utterly inflexible little robot!
(You're the last person who should be calling anybody "inflexible"...)
Ha ha! You remind me of my grandchild who just learned his own name. Oh, how precious!
All right, Ponco... I'm going to ask you some questions.
Questions? You have questions? Hooray! What are your questions?
I want to know if you were there at the scene of the murder of Metis Cykes. It was seven years ago, on the 7th of October around 2 PM, in the robotics lab.
Certainly! Just one moment! Searching data............ Search complete! Yes, I was there in the robotics lab!
It would seem this robot's testimony is necessary to this case after all.
(This is great! I just KNEW Ponco must've seen something important!)
A murder committed right before this poor little girl's eyes! It's inexcusable!
(The judge seems ready to adopt Ponco as another grandchild...)
So, little Ponco, do you think you can give us your testimony today...?
I went to the robotics lab at about 2 PM for my regular recharge!
Well, it sounds like the defendant was, without question, at the scene. However, it doesn't appear that the witness saw the actual moment of the murder.
I disagree. This testimony shows that the defendant did indeed commit the crime.
...What?
At the end of the day, we mustn't forget that this witness is still a machine. Being a robot, its understanding and capacity to express itself are limited.
S-So what are you suggesting?
The witness's statements need to be interpreted. For example, the terms "hugged," and then, later, "fell down." Adults don't usually fall down after being hugged by a child.
They don't, but...!
Yes. What this witness's statements are telling us is... ...that the defendant stabbed the victim with the murder weapon during this moment!
WH-AAAAAAAAAAAAAT?!
Before Ms. Cykes hugged Dr. Cykes, did the two of them converse?
Yes, they did. They spoke to each other very loudly! But I don't know what they said. Athena is usually so quiet, so I was surprised!
"Spoke very loudly." We can interpret this to mean "they argued."

I see. Murder after a heated argument... And then the victim "fell down." I agree that it does sound like a reasonable interpretation. However, Ponco doesn't seem to remember anything that happened after that.
When I am recharging, I go into sleep mode. But I remember everything before that! I have a very good memory!
You may as well admit defeat now, Wright; a cross-examination would be useless.
D-Don't be ridiculous! A cross-examination is never useless!
Until now. Think about it! Robots don't lie. This robot is both an important witness and valuable evidence at the same time.
Nevertheless... I will have my cross-examination!
Hmph. I see you haven't changed. You never were one to worry about wasting time.
Very well. Even if it may be a waste of time, you may proceed, Mr. Wright.
(I'll show you both just how fruitful any cross-examination can be!)
I went to the robotics lab at about 2 PM for my regular recharge!
Phoenix:
I have to refill my battery's power or else I stop working! I go to the lab to do that.
So that recharge occurred around 2 PM, around the time of the murder?
That's right! I go every day at 2 PM!
Just as I was about to charge up, Athena came in and hugged Mommy Metis!
Phoenix:
Yes, they were talking very loudly. But I couldn't tell what they were saying.
Couldn't tell? Even though they were talking so loudly?
I'm only allowed to listen to voices that are directed at me.
Hmph. If it listened to every voice, it would be little better than a mobile eavesdropper.
(Well, that explains why some of Ponco's testimony is so vague...)
It's a shame that our little friend wasn't listening in, however. We could've learned what they were talking about just before Dr. Cykes was killed. Now then, what happened after that?
And then Mommy Metis fell down. After that, I was recharging, so I don't know anything.
Phoenix:
Mommy Metis was very surprised when she was hugged. I heard her heart pound.
Her heart...?
Mr. Wright, have you forgotten about this document we found in the robotics lab? These robots have a heartbeat detection system.

(Now that he mentions it, I do remember reading something like that there... They detect the presence of people by the sound of their heartbeats. But wait a minute... That means... ...if Dr. Cykes really did die at this moment...) Ponco, how was Dr. Cykes after she fell down? Could you still hear the sound of her heartbeat?
Let's see. The moment she fell, her heart was pounding. After that, I don't know. I started recharging just then.
Of all the unlucky timing! If you had heard anything after that... ...it could have possibly proved that the hug wasn't actually the moment of the murder!
I'm very sorry. I'm afraid I don't know. I'm very sorry...
The robot is designed to go into sleep mode automatically, so it can't be helped... But it does appear it detected an increased heart rate at the moment of the stabbing.
Ngh...
After Mommy Metis's heart started pounding in surprise, she fell by the window. It was the round window, on the workbench side of the room!
(The workbench, huh...? Ponco must be talking about that table to the right of where that giant robot is now. Is there something critical in Ponco's statement just now?)
Your Honor, I believe this statement is critical. I'd like it added to her testimony!
Very well. Ponco, could you please add that statement to your testimony? That's a good little girl!
"Mommy Metis fell down near the round window on the workbench side of the room!"
............ (Nothing particularly important, I guess.) So, what happened after that, Ponco?
Phoenix:
Mommy Metis was very surprised when she was hugged. I heard her heart pound.
Her heart...?
Mr. Wright, have you forgotten about this document we found in the robotics lab? These robots have a heartbeat detection system.

(Now that he mentions it, I do remember reading something like that there... They detect the presence of people by the sound of their heartbeats. But wait a minute... That means... ...if Dr. Cykes really did die at this moment...) Ponco, how was Dr. Cykes after she fell down? Could you still hear the sound of her heartbeat?
Let's see. The moment she fell, her heart was pounding. After that, I don't know. I started recharging just then.
Of all the unlucky timing! If you had heard anything after that... ...it could have possibly proved that the hug wasn't actually the moment of the murder!
I'm very sorry. I'm afraid I don't know. I'm very sorry...
The robot is designed to go into sleep mode automatically, so it can't be helped... But it does appear it detected an increased heart rate at the moment of the stabbing.
Ngh...
After Mommy Metis's heart started pounding in surprise, she fell by the window. It was the round window, on the workbench side of the room!
(The workbench, huh...? Ponco must be talking about that table to the right of where that giant robot is now.)
Mommy Metis fell down near the round window on the workbench side of the room!
Phoenix:
The one on the right, near the hanging scroll! That hanging scroll was Mommy Metis's prized possession!

(Okay, in the pictures of the crime scene from seven years ago, there is definitely... ...a hanging scroll and a Japanese theater mask hanging on the workbench-side wall. But is there some problem with this statement...?)
Leads to:
After I charged up, I was cleaning the room, and Mr. Simon came in.
Phoenix:
His objective? I don't know! I don't know!
(Hmm... I guess I can't very well ask Ponco to speculate...) So what happened after Prosecutor Blackquill arrived?
And then an error occurred. There is no data after that point.
Phoenix:
All data is suddenly cut off at that point. I don't know anything after that!
The answer to that question is right here. According to the defense's theory, this photo shows when the robot was being taken apart.
Exactly. We can conclude that... ...Ponco's "error" was the result of her being dismantled.
Indeed. The bodies of these robots are designed to be controlled remotely... ...by a separate computer.
(Yes, that's basically what Ms. Blackquill explained to us, too. She said their hearts and memories are stored on a separate computer.)
When the witness was taken apart, she lost the use of her body, but not her memories. That's how she is now still able to give testimony about the events of that day.
Fascinating. It's as if she can be seriously wounded, but her soul still burns.

(There are a few parts of Ponco's testimony that are hard to interpret. Edgeworth chose to interpret "hugged" as "stabbed"... ...but I'd better try to iron out who did what where and to whom for myself... Hold on, Athena! I'm going to save you!)
Ponco, your statement may have just inspired a breakthrough.
I was helpful? Hooray! I'm so happy!
Just to be sure, let's go over it again, okay? The victim fell near the window on the workbench side of the room. However... ...her body was discovered on the operating table.
B-But the operating table and the workbench are two different locations!
Exactly, Your Honor! We've just learned a new, crucial fact! What could explain the two very different locations of the body? I'll tell you what!
The fact that the body was observed in two very different locations... ...indicates that the defendant moved the body!
Hmm... That does seem like a plausible explanation.
............ Is that really your final answer?
Huh...? OH! (He's right! A little kid couldn't possibly move an adult body like that! And the last thing I want to do is cast more suspicion Athena's way!)
Mr. Wright...? Your response...?
Um, can you just forget I ever said that, Your Honor? Please...?
I can't, and I won't. As a matter of fact, here is a little reminder for YOU as well!
Aaaaaagh! (Ngh... I really need to think this through. What could explain the two locations...?) Let me try that again, Your Honor!

An eleven-year-old girl couldn't have moved the heavy body of an adult. So the only explanation is that the victim walked to the operating table herself. In other words, what Ponco observed near the workbench... ...couldn't possibly have been the moment of the murder!
Whew. I am relieved to hear that. Glad to know that the murder wasn't committed in front of little Ponco here.
Yes, as we just heard in the testimony, Ms. Cykes hugged her mother, nothing more.
Edgeworth:
